ARABIC: لَا فِيهَا غَوْلٌ وَلَا هُمْ عَنْهَا يُنزَفُونَ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: which has no headache in it and does not leave them stupefied.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: Neither dulling the senses nor intoxicating,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: There will neither be any harm in it for their body nor will it intoxicate their mind.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: Neither does it intoxicate, nor give a headache.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: Neither will they have Ghawl from that nor will they suffer intoxication therefrom.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: There shall be no trouble in it, nor shall they be exhausted therewith.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: wherein no sickness is, neither intoxication;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: Wherein there is no headache nor are they made mad thereby.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: No headiness there shall be therein, nor shall they be therewith Inebriated.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: wherein there will be neither headache nor will it cause them stupefaction,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: Free from headiness; nor will they suffer intoxication therefrom.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Neither they will have Ghoul (any kind of hurt, abdominal pain, headache, a sin, etc.) from that, nor will they suffer intoxication therefrom.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: there is neither sickness in it, nor intoxication.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: No bad effect is there in it, nor from it will they be intoxicated.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [37:47] wherein there is neither madness, nothing to snatch away their minds, nor will they be spent by it (read yunzafūna or yunzifūna, from [1st form] nazafa or [4th form] anzafa, said of one drinking, in other words, they are [not] inebriated [by it], in contrast to the wine of this world),
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: Wherein) in drinking this wine (there is no headache) stomach-ache, drunkenness, harm or sinning (nor are they made mad thereby) because of intoxication; it is also said that this means: they never run out of it.
